The incomplete success of the plan for the <hi rend="smallcaps">Works</hi> II illustrations arose paradoxically from Pope’s gaining more direct control over the printing and publishing of<lb/>his work. The 1717 volume, though closely supervised by Pope, was published by<lb/>one of the trade’s most successful booksellers, Bernard Lintot, and printed by one<lb/>of its most distinguished printers, William Bowyer. It everywhere shows signs of<lb/>generous investment. In comparison the 1735 volume was something of a scram-<lb/>ble. By the time <hi rend="smallcaps">Works</hi> II was published Pope was financing his own publications<lb/>and working with the young bookseller Lawton Gilliver and the experienced but<lb/>unspectacular printer John Wright.<lb/>As money-sparing as he was paper-sparing,<lb/>Pope’s aim seems to have been to publish his poems first individually but with<lb/>extra sheets printed so that they could be used for the <hi rend="smallcaps">Works</hi>. That project was,<lb/>however, at odds with his constant itch to revise, and the resulting volumes of<lb/><hi rend="smallcaps">Works</hi> are combinations of new printings and sheets published at various earlier<lb/>times. Their incoherent collations reflect their piecemeal assemblage, and the<lb/>texts in the three formats can be significantly different. The engravings show the<lb/>consequences of this cheese-paring approach. There were to be new engravings<lb/>for the <hi rend="italic">Dunciad</hi>, where Gilliver owned the copyright and would have had to pay,<lb/>but the general money-saving plan was to decorate the book with the plates that<lb/>had been prepared by William Kent and Paul Fourdrinier for Pope’s translation<lb/>of the <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi> (1725–6). Pope eventually proved willing to pay for modification of<lb/>the <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi> engravings and for some new ones to emphasize the thematic unity of<lb/>the two books of ‘Epistles’, but the reuse of the <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi> plates draws attention away<lb/>from what was potentially a coherent plan for illustration of the <hi rend="smallcaps">Works</hi>.<lb/>
<head>The Plan for <hi rend="smallcaps">Works</hi> II (1735)</head><lb/>
The <hi rend="smallcaps">Works</hi> falls into four sections, marked by heraldic headpieces and tailpieces.<lb/>Pat Rogers has demonstrated that some of the early work in Pope’s career had<lb/>a heraldic underpinning, especially the imagery in <hi rend="italic">Windsor-Forest</hi> (1713), which<lb/>Rogers connects with the Stuart claim to the throne.<lb/>In 1735 heraldry was used<lb/>to mark Pope’s social status and commitments.<lb/>
The first section consists of the four epistles of <hi rend="italic">An Essay on Man</hi>, addressed to<lb/>Henry St.&nbsp;John, Viscount Bolingbroke, the leader of the opposition to Sir Robert<lb/>Walpole’s ministry. It begins with an engraving including his coat of arms.<lb/>
